passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Lysippus, Sicyonian sculptor, bold in spirit, who set the standard for bronze

evidence_items.rationale: Athenaeus preserves epigram on Lysippus, attribution to Posidippus

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Made Alexander seem the way he was, and gave his form to all the world to see

evidence_items.rationale: Continuation of Lysippus epigram, specific reference to Alexander

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For this is how Zeus looked, gazing from heaven, when on the son of Philip he bestowed the power to rule

evidence_items.rationale: The divine comparison fits Posidippan style and Hellenistic ruler cult

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: The artist's hand, more skillful than nature's own, captured in stone the very soul of beauty

evidence_items.rationale: Milan papyrus contains art epigrams with similar themes

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: You ask me what I suffer, knowing well yourself, the same sweet fire that burns within my breast

evidence_items.rationale: PA preserves Posidippan erotic epigrams with attribution

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For when I look on you, my voice fails me, my tongue is broken, and subtle fire runs beneath my skin

evidence_items.rationale: Typical Hellenistic erotic topoi, consistent with Posidippan style

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: This gift I send, a token of my love, small in size but great in what it means

evidence_items.rationale: PA preserves dedicatory/erotic epigram with gift theme

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For even the smallest gift, when given with love, outweighs all treasures of the wealthy kings

evidence_items.rationale: Pointed closure typical of epigrammatic style, moralizing tone

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: The morning star has risen, and the night is gone, yet still I lie awake, thinking of you
Sleep flees from my eyes, and rest from my limbs, for love has made the night as bright as day

evidence_items.rationale: Continuation of insomnia theme, conventional topoi

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: He who once was victor in the sacred games, whose name was praised throughout the stadium

evidence_items.rationale: Milan papyrus contains athletic victory/death epigrams

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Now lies beneath this stone, his glory faded, his strength consumed by all-devouring death

evidence_items.rationale: Continuation of athletic epigram, typical mortal theme

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: The sea that bore them, the same sea destroyed them, as they sailed homeward with their wealthy cargo
For fate is fickle, and fortune's wheel turns round, bringing low the proud, raising up the humble

evidence_items.rationale: Moralizing conclusion typical of Hellenistic epigram

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Muses, daughters of Memory, who know all things, grant skill to my hands and wisdom to my heart

evidence_items.rationale: Milan papyrus contains invocations and dedicatory epigrams

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For without you, all learning is but noise, and wisdom but an empty sounding name

evidence_items.rationale: Pointed closure typical of dedicatory epigram

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Philaenis to Aphrodite dedicates this mirror, no longer needed, for her beauty fades

evidence_items.rationale: Dedicatory epigram with Aphrodite, typical of PA collection

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: What once reflected youth's bright glow now shows the wrinkles time has carved

evidence_items.rationale: Continuation of mirror dedication, mortal theme
